explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_solids.rationale: Non-combustible (BGIA, GESTIS-database on hazardous substancess, Accessed in 2006)

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive or self-reactive properties present in the molecule.

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Non-combustible (BGIA, GESTIS-database on hazardous substancess, Accessed in 2006)

self_heating_substances.rationale: Non-combustible (GESTIS-database on hazardous substances, accessed in 2006)

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Stable to water (the water solubility is obtained)

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: SPECIES: Rat ENDPOINT: LD50 VALUE: > 5000 mg/kg REFERENCE SOURCE: IUCLID (2000)

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: There is the test using a rabbit that reports "there is no irritation"(IUCLID (2000)). But it cannot be classified since the detail were not understood and the data is insufficient.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Although there is the description that "it has no irritation" in the test using rabbit (IUCLID (2000)), the details are insufficient. Hence it cannot be classified.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause allergy or asthma symptoms or breathing difficulties if inhaled
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Although there is no report of this material itself, chromium and chromium compound were classified into "the 2nd group (material considered that there is probably sensitizing to human)" in Japan Association of Industrial Health, and chromium was classified into the material with respiratory sensitization in Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy Special Committee, this product thought that it had respiratory sensitization and was set to Category 1.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: In Japan Society for Occupational Health, although there was no report of this material itself, since chromium and chromium compound were classified into "the 1st group (material which has sensitizing clearly to human)", this product thought that it had skin sensitization, and was set to Category 1.

carcinogenicity.rationale: No data. In addition, although this product is the insoluble hexavalent chromium compounds, the mutagenicity knowledge in in vivo is indicated about many flood solubility hexavalent chromium compounds (NTP RoC (11th, 2005), IARC49 (1990), EU-RAR (2005)). Refer to potassium dichromate (ID 262, Chemical Abstracts Service:7778-50-9). Moreover, inorganic lead compounds describes that a chromosome aberration is induced to humans in ATSDR (draft, 2005), and is classified into the germ cell mutagenicities 3A (equivalent to GHS Category 1B-2) in MAK/BAT (2005).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: As hexavalent chromium compounds, since it was was classified K (Chromium hexavalent (VI) compounds) in NTP (2005), group 1 (Chromium(VI)) in IARC (1990), and A (Chromium(VI), Inhalation route) in EPA (1986), respectively. So it was classified into Category 1A.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May damage fertility or the unborn child
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Although there is no this product data, there is the description that a lead (inorganic lead compound) shows humans reproductive toxicity (ATSDR (draft, 2005), Chemically Induced Birth Defects (3rd ed, 2000)), and it was set as Category 1A due to the category of reproductive toxicity has been done also by ACGIH (ACGIH-TLV (2005)). In addition, also refer to potassium dichromate (ID 262, CAS: 7778-50-9) as reproductive toxicity of hexavalent chromium compounds.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (central nervous system, blood, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Although there is no data about this product, since "symptom that the acute influence of inorganic leads and chronic influence are almost the same is observed " about humans, as toxicity of the inorganic lead compounds (CERI Hazard Data 2001-9, 2002), in ACGIH-TLV (2005), it effects on the central nervous systems, blood, and renal as inorganic leads compound, it was considered as Category 1 (a central nervous system, blood, kidney). In addition, there is description that when oral or percutaneous absorption is carried out as acute toxicities of the hexavalent chromium compound, vomiting, diarrhea, a spasm, a hemorrhagic nephritis, etc. are caused (DFGOT vol.3 (1992), DHP (13th, 2002)). Moreover, the influence on blood (anemia) (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and respiratory irritant (HSDB (2003)) are mentioned as toxicity of molybdenum.

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (central nervous system, blood, kidney)
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Although there was no data of this product, as an inorganic lead compound, it effects on central nervous systems, blood, and kidney (ACGIH-TLV (2005) in Priority 1 document). It was classified into Category 1 (central nervous system, blood, kidney). In addition, there is a description of effects on kidneys, nasal septum perforation, ulcers, etc. as chronic toxicity of hexavalent chromium compounds (ACGIH (7th, 2001), IRIS (1998), DHP (13th, 2002)). Moreover, as toxicity of molybdenum, effects on blood (anemia) and lungs (pneumoconiosis) are mentioned (PATTY (5th, 2001), HSDB (2003)).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: May cause long lasting harmful effects to aquatic life
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 4, since it is a metallic compound, and behavior in water is unknown, though no acute toxicity is reported within the saturated aqueous solution.
